page.title: 01KETTLEWELL, NORTH YORKSHIRE
page.content: Kettlewell is in Upper Wharfedale, and is a Conservation Area within the Yorkshire Dales National Park, 14 miles north of Skipton. The River Wharfe flows south through a glacial valley with banks of meadow and pasture land. Upland rough grazing and limestone scars reach to the bleaker moor-tops. The lower areas are well clad with trees. Dry stone walls divide the hillsides roughly into rectangles, many of great length and height, constructed after the Enclosure Acts. Cam Beck flows though the village from Gt. Whernside, joined by Dowber Gill Beck, to meet the Wharfe. All can rise rapidly to cause flash fooding. Numerous shake-holes, pot-holes, disused lead-mines, bell-pits and caves riddle the area. Evidence of early settlements can be clearly seen.
